ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a bit about music and styles of music.

This course gave me a stronger understanding of the historical development of Cuban and Jamaican people starting from westward movement into the Caribbean. While the focus is music, we talked through many socio-political factors of both throughout history and we also discussed other places in the world as Cubans or Jamaicans moved there and made music (like NYC or the UK).

I learned a lot about the intersections of music, culture, history, and politics. We really grasped how Cuban and Jamaican music reflected and produced new national identities. As someone who had limited technical knowledge of music, this course also offered a great introduction to that vocabulary.

I gained a vast knowledge of the liturgical practices of african peoples and how that translated into modern music today. We learned so much about the artists who transformed the music we listen to today and what historical events influenced it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was not super engaging. Your grades are mostly based on two essays, which isnt great. I think its a cool subject they Professor Veal is passionate about but I didnt really engage with the content. If we did things like dance to the music one day or watch a live band perform another it would have helped make this class memorable.
I really enjoyed the format of the course.
The course is phenomenal. Prof. Veal created a wonderful syllabus with compelling readings and class discussion was rarely slow. I loved the class, there were no weaknesses.
Strengths: extremely engaging, and very understanding of students personal situations and offered grace.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Maybe. Its not a hard class, but I wasnt excited to learn about it after a while because the class wasnt that fun. Its also a lot of class time for one day a week.

I would! Professor Veal brings a candidness and knowledge to his classroom that allows any class to really make what they want of it. If you lack historical or musical background, there is space to ask- the TFs even facilitated extra content sessions to help level the knowledge base of the class. This class helps place Carribbean history, music, and blackness in conversation, so if you already have a grasp one piece, the class is a great way to expand more into learning about the others.
Absolutely. You dont need any prior knowledge of Cuba or Jamaica to take or do well in this course. I think especially for students of Caribbean descent, this class has special significance.
Absolutely. One of my favorites at Yale.
YES!!! 1000% yes! Professor Veal is incredible and makes you want to come to class every day prepared for another great discussion

extras.title: AFAM 479 01/MUSI 480 01 - Music of Cuba and Jamaica
